node.text:
The pandemic not only disrupted education—it also thrust technology onto a sector which historically has been slow to adopt it. Will classrooms ever be the same again?

Cover image credit: Ben Hasty/MediaNews Group/Reading Eagle via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: how tech will transform your kids’ education

node.text: The race between covid-19 vaccines and variants is on. Alok Jha, The Economist’s science correspondent, and Natasha Loder, our health policy editor, discuss what this means for the future. Cover image credit: Alamy

node.title: Covid-19: can vaccines keep up with variants?

node.text: The Taliban’s swift return to power in Afghanistan has shocked the world and humiliated America. What effect will this have on the international standing of the US and on global security? Our experts answer your questions. Cover credit: AP

node.title: Afghanistan: how the Taliban weakened America

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.text:
Most governments recognise that vaccination is the fastest way out of the pandemic, but in many places hesitancy is hindering the roll-out. Should employers—or even governments—force people to have the vaccine? We answer your questions.

Cover image credit:

node.text:
The covid-19 pandemic has reinforced humanity’s dependence on modern tech, but the same tools that enable remote working are also being used to spread disinformation and perpetuate cybercrime. Ambivalence towards technology is nothing new.

Cover image credit: Scott Strazzante/The San Francisco Chronicle via Getty Images

node.text:
More than 50 countries around the world have pledged to become net zero. But what does net zero actually mean—and is it achievable?

Cover image credit: Brandon Thibodeaux/ The New York Times / Redux / eyevine

node.text:
In the past couple of weeks South Africa has witnessed the worst violence since the end of apartheid in 1994. Our correspondent in Johannesburg explains what he has seen on the streets and why the country is in crisis. 

Cover credit: Getty Images

node.title: South Africa: what's behind the riots?

node.text:
In America, the intelligence services deem far-right extremism a greater domestic threat than Islamist terrorism. The pandemic has exacerbated the spread of white supremacism and neo-Nazism.

Cover image credit: Michael Nigro/Pacific Press/LightRocket via Getty Images

node.title: Fortnite to far right: the rise of digital extremism

node.text:
Across much of the world, covid-19 restrictions are starting to ease. The Economist has crunched the data to calculate how close countries are to pre-pandemic levels of normality—but will life ever be the same again? 

Click on the link in our bio to visit our website and explore our interactive normalcy tracker. It covers 50 countries which account for 76% of the world’s population and 90% of its GDP.

Cover image credit: Lluis Gene/AFP via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: why your life will never be the same again

node.text: For most of 2020 the theory that covid-19 leaked from a Chinese lab was dismissed as unlikely. In the past few months it has gained currency. Our experts explain why. Cover credit: Getty Images

node.title: Did covid-19 leak from a Chinese lab?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in London, United Kingdom.

node.text:
The end of the summer feels too early to be thinking about Christmas, but retailers in Britain have little choice. ⁠
⁠
The typical household spends around a third more than usual in December, and stocking up for the most important trading weeks of the year usually begins around now. ⁠
⁠
This year, however, rather than preparing for the coming rush, retailers are struggling to keep shelves full.⁠
⁠
So what is causing shortages in Britain? Tap the link in our bio to read about the bottlenecks, and how covid-19 and Brexit have reshaped the economy.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @lo_cole

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in Malang. May be an image of one or more people and text.

node.text:
Sunti Ani has been arrested more times than she can count. Her crime is being a sex worker in Indonesia.⁠
⁠
She lives in Malang, in the province of East Java, where her trade was criminalised in 2014 on the basis that prostitution is “prohibited by all religions”.⁠
⁠
The ban has meant that sex workers’ earnings fell and some compensated by offering clients unprotected sex, for which they can charge more.⁠
⁠
Public-health measures have suffered as well. Many prostitutes in Malang lost access to cheap condoms and checks for sexually transmitted infections.⁠
⁠
But two brothels in a nearby district remained open. Click the link in our bio to read how this in turn created a natural experiment about infection rates in those premises.⁠
⁠
Image credit: Ulet Ifansasti/Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 06, 2021. May be a cartoon of text that says 'International From Congo to the Capitol, conspiracy theories are surging ? HOAX! 3m 42.5m views $'.

node.text:
The pandemic has produced a tsunami of misinformation—and the internet makes it easier than ever to spread it.⁠
⁠
In France a documentary alleging that covid-19 was invented by political elites as part of a conspiracy to bring about a “new world order” was watched 2.5m times in three days.⁠
⁠
And in America the notion that covid is a hoax has spread alongside a collection of feverish theories known as “QAnon”, which hold that the government is run by a secret cabal of paedophiles and that Donald Trump is a saviour destined to defeat them. There are 45 believers in QAnon running for Congress in 2022.⁠
⁠
This is, in short, a golden age of conspiracy theories. They are at least as common in poor countries as in rich ones.⁠
⁠
Bonkers beliefs have existed throughout history. But to get a sense of how they infect politics today, a good place to start is the Democratic Republic of Congo. To read why, and to learn how they can be discouraged, click on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @wylesol_

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The future future of American power " It simply is not enough to claim, if it is correct, that America remains number one Paul Kennedy'.

node.text:
America has a new contender for supremacy: China.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Writing in The Economist, historian Paul Kennedy argues that changes in global politics, armed forces and economics mark a "very significant redistribution of world power".⁠⁠
⁠⁠
"The international system now comprises four or maybe five very large states," he writes. "None of them can, either through hard power or soft power, compel the others to do what they don’t want to do."⁠⁠
⁠⁠
"It simply is not enough to claim, if it is correct, that America remains number one: for even if it is the biggest gorilla in the jungle, it is only one of a bunch of gorillas!"⁠⁠
⁠⁠
So, does China's rise mean America's fall? To read why Paul Kennedy believes "an amazing flip" is happening in world affairs, click on the link in our bio.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Illustration: @dan.will

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The future future of American power " It simply is not enough to claim, if it is correct, that America remains number one Paul Kennedy'.
Photo by The Economist on September 06, 2021. May be an illustration of 1 person.

Photo by The Economist on September 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Economic activity is spreading outward from city centres Economic-activity index*, 2021 % change from pre-pandemic baselinet National average -20 -40 Paris Jan 60 Feb Mar Apr May Jun -80 *Visits to sites of retail and recreation, workplaces and transit stations Seven-day moving average Jul Aug Sources: Google; The Economist The Economist'.

node.text:
Before covid-19 cities seemed invincible.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
But the exodus from urban areas at the start of the pandemic, which was motivated by fear of catching the virus and which many assumed would be temporary, now looks more permanent and indicative of a deeper shift in preferences.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The big question is whether this is something to worry about.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
To take the pulse of global cities, we constructed an “exodus index”, using Google data on visits to sites of retail and recreation, public transport and workplaces, and which compares mobility in large cities with that in their respective countries.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
As these charts show, in America, Britain, France and Japan activity remains substantially lower in cities than it does nationally.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Economic activity is gradually seeping outward from the centre—but opinion is divided on whether this is a good thing. To learn more about the new economics of global cities, tap on the link in our bio.

May be an image of text that says 'Economic activity is spreading outward from city centres Economic-activity index*, 2021 % change from pre-pandemic baselinet National average -20 -40 Manhattan 60 Feb Mar Apr May Jun Jan *Visits to sites of retail and recreation, workplaces and transit stations *Seven-day moving average -80 Jul Aug Sources: Google; The Economist The Economist'.
Photo by The Economist on September 06, 2021. May be an image of motorcycle, mountain and text that says 'Asia The Taliban appear to have taken Afghanistan's last bastion of resistance'.

node.text:
Ahmad Shah Masoud fought the Soviets and the Taliban from the Panjshir valley for decades. ⁠
⁠
His son’s resistance has crumbled in less than a month. ⁠
⁠
After a weekend of fierce fighting, a Taliban spokesperson said that the group had taken “complete control” of Panjshir province. ⁠
⁠
Ahmad Masoud had hoped Panjshir would hold out until the winter. His apparent aim was to cut a deal with the Taliban to guarantee the area’s long-standing autonomy, but that is now unlikely. Tap the link in our bio to read why.⁠
⁠
Credit: Ahmad Sahel Arman/AFP via Getty Images

node.text:
“It’s called a heartbeat bill. But that’s really a misnomer.”⁠
⁠
Last week, the Supreme Court allowed legislation in Texas to stand—the most restrictive abortion law in America.⁠
⁠
It’s far beyond the boundaries of the landmark 1973 judgement of Roe vs Wade and later decisions that say abortion for any reason should be accessible to women until the fetus is viable, which is at about 24 weeks.⁠
⁠
Courts have previously blocked heartbeat bills before they could even be implemented. But Texas's law is now very much in force and it's the most draconian in the country, our SCOTUS correspondent explains on “The Intelligence”. ⁠
⁠
Will other states copy Texas, and what what does this tell us about abortion rights in SCOTUS, or America more generally? To find out, tap the link in bio to listen to today’s podcast.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in Conakry, Guinea. May be an image of outdoors and text that says 'Middle East & Africa An apparent coup may signal the end of Alpha Condé's rule in Guinea T YOT 2501973'.

node.text:
A military coup in Guinea appears to have succeeded in ousting President Alpha Condé.⁠
⁠
Yet the country’s Ministry of Defence maintains that the "threat" was put down. Mr Condé’s whereabouts are unconfirmed.⁠
⁠
If this is the end of his rule it marks both a sorry finale to a presidency that once promised much—and a dangerous new moment for Guinea's long-suffering 13m people.⁠
⁠
The soldiers have promised talks and an “inclusive and peaceful transition” but there is no clear indication of how long they plan to stay in power. To read why Guinea’s recent history provides reason to worry, click on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Credit: Cellou Binani / AFP

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 05, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Business Why people are always so gloomy about the world of work 0 ON ~ INC.'.

node.text:
The notion that the modern economy lacks “good jobs” is as uncontroversial as saying that Lionel Messi is good at football. ⁠
⁠
Critics of capitalism have long said that working life is in decay. In fact, the notion is as old as capitalism itself. ⁠
⁠Few people during America’s post-war boom believed they were living in a golden age of labour. And there is little evidence to suggest that workers back then were any happier than they are today. ⁠
⁠
But today's world of work is far better than its critics would like to admit. So why is the jobs-are-bad narrative so pervasive—and intuitive? Tap the link in our bio to find out. ⁠
⁠
Illustration: @ilovechickenkiev

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in Beijing, China.

node.text:
It is time to introduce Xi Jinping Thought on Socialism with Chinese Characteristics for the New Era—as the Chinese president’s political philosophy is formally known.⁠
⁠
As the academic year began on September 1st, teachers and lecturers began distributing this new series of textbooks to all students in Chinese schools, colleges and universities.⁠
⁠
The last time that hundreds of millions of youngsters clutched books devoted to the wisdom of one man was under Mao Zedong, the object (and instigator) of a disastrous personality cult.⁠
⁠
But, in many ways, it is not the same. Click the link in our bio to learn what "Grandpa Xi Jinping" really wants from China's youngsters.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @hannabarczyk

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 05, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Science & technology Why have some some female hummingbirds evolved to look like males?'.

node.text:
⁠Female hummingbirds seem to have mastered the art of disguise.⁠
⁠
Male birds are often colourful and ornate, demonstrating that they are both suitable candidates for fatherhood and are not to be messed with by other males.⁠
⁠
Yet why females are sometimes colourful too is more of a mystery.⁠
⁠
One idea is that if the sexes co-operate to raise their young—which birds often do—males as well as females must be choosy about their mates. ⁠
⁠
But in a recent paper, Jay Falk of the University of Washington has offered up a new explanation: to avoid being harassed when they are feeding. ⁠
⁠
To read how he reached this conclusion, and what else it reveals about hummingbirds, click on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Credit: Alamy

node.text:
How can war criminals be brought to justice? And what is the role of interpreters within institutions like the International Criminal Court? Host Anne McElvoy asks Katie Kitamura on this week’s “The Economist Asks” podcast.⁠
⁠
Also on the episode, the author of “Intimacies” reveals why she drew inspiration from the ICC and its interpreters for her new book. She explores the power of language and the pitfalls of mistranslation. As the daughter of immigrants to the US, Ms Kitamura talks about where she feels most at home and the secret to marital bliss.⁠
⁠
To hear whether Anne and Katie still have faith in the International Criminal Court, click the link in our bio to listen to “The Economist Asks”.
